body: Closing this since this will be superceded by the PR for REEF-217.

I've retried tests with merged #898. Previous test failures don't reappear, but I have a new one:

```
Test Name:  Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Utility.TestDriverConfigGenerator.TestGeneratingFullDriverConfigFile

Result Message: 
System.InvalidOperationException : Failed to extract files from jar file with stdout :and stderr:java.util.zip.ZipError: jzentry == 0,
 jzfile = 1364566832,
 total = 6067,
 name = .\reef-bridge-java-0.15.0-SNAPSHOT-shaded.jar,
 i = 3922,
 message = null
at java.util.zip.ZipFile$1.nextElement(ZipFile.java:505)
at java.util.zip.ZipFile$1.nextElement(ZipFile.java:483)
at sun.tools.jar.Main.extract(Main.java:951)
at sun.tools.jar.Main.run(Main.java:258)
at sun.tools.jar.Main.main(Main.java:1231)
```

I suspect that since our tests extract .jar file each for itself, when some of them run in parallel, one can try and get information while the other one is re-extracting the file. I think we should open a separate JIRA to clarify/fix the way we're extracting .jar files so that they are extracted only once per run and no test gets them broken.

As for splitting the change in two, personally I feel it would be a good thing to do to separate the logic of two parts - which part is needed to introduce LocalAddressProvider and which part to use it in tests - not just to reduce the number of files in the change.
I just reran the tests as well, on a different Windows 10 machine. Here, I don't get the firewall messages. And all tests passed. I rebased to current `master` before running the tests, though.

Should we make sure there are no firewall messages on all machines we can get? Or can we write off the first result as an outlier?
(I rebased to current master as well when testing)

> Or can we write off the first result as an outlier?

Maybe. It isn't an outlier though. I can repeat it on my other machine.
Looking into this further: I get no dialog boxes on that machine if I disable all network connections. Interesting.

@markusweimer I updated the PR with changes as described in this thread: Added bridge API that retrieves currently defined runtimes. Each runtime binds provided runtime names (single name for all runitmes, and all supported runtimes for multi).
@markusweimer I ran Yarn tests + HelloREEF c# on Yarn.
LGTM. Will merge.
Thank you!

@shulmanb done with a first pass. The main concern here is how we can expose the closing of a connection, and _who_ should close the connection. Would it still be a "manager" if the client were to be the one managing the closing of connections? Or should we merely create a new `Factory` that provides a similar function?
@markusweimer Could you take a look and see if my latest push fixed it? It seems like `HostAddress` and `LocalAddressProvider` serve the same purpose. Perhaps we should deprecate `HostAddress`?
Testing now.

@afchung I agree with your concern, however I would not go to a separate factory as the current one is broken (once tcp connection is broken teh only way to recover is to recreate the manager). The only other option I can think of is to return an instance of a class that implements both IObservable and IDisposable, but then we iwll have the opposite problem, what if someone will dispose shared connection?
WDYT?
@markusweimer Do you have an opinion on this issue?
@afchung HOw about returning out own class that implements IObserver and IDisposable and when the remote manager will cache the connection it will throw if Dispose will be invoked?
@markusweimer Can you please take a look?
I will review it
This change allows to get correct version. I'll merge
Testing the latest commit now.

Good news: No firewall was triggered by this.

@shulmanb If you fix the `RemoteManager` to return your own class that implements `IDisposable` _and_ `IObserver`, it will break backward compatibility for users, which is why I proposed to write a new `RemoteObserverFactory` instead of using the `RemoteManager` for returning disposable remote observers. The naming also makes sense, since if the state of the connections were directly managed by the user, `RemoteManager` won't be a "manager" anymore, but just a factory.

It won't be just a factory, as it will still have register observer functionality. I don't see any reason to create a factory for just outgoing connections as it will require people to use both the factory and manager to achieve the needed functionality. Returning our own class won't really Brea current users as the expect observable and will get an observable. I can go with NonCachingManager that will provide same functionality as current managers but will actually work. In my opinion the current implementation doesn't work at all as the connections remain broken after first failure without the ability to recreate a connection.

Nevermind, I forgot to rebase onto `master` before testing. After I rebased, the tests did not fail, but hung in the Wake tests. After a restart, tests are failing again. Something is off on this machine, it seems.
Which tests are failing? Some of the local runtime tests are not put in the right collection so conflicts occur when trying to read the output file, since the tests will be run in parallel.

Shouldn't they all have separate runtime folders and thus separate output files? Or is it the tests which depend on TestNumber so can have same runtime folder when executed in parallel? I want to clean out TestNumber as part of REEF-1265, as it's clearly not suited for parallel execution.

@afchung, @markusweimer  I am not sure it makes sense to have just the remote observers factory. If you will look on what is currently implemented, each remote observer is a two ways communication channel, it allows to both write and read, and reads are delegated to the registered observers (that are disposables). So the non caching implementation is still a remote manager, not a factory. Probably the best option is to introduce additional methods to the IRemoteManager interface that will create NonCachableRemoteObservers that will implement both IObserver and IDisposable. We should also think if we want to keep the current implementation for long as , in my opinion, it is fundamentally broken
@afchung Uploaded new version with separate factory method for non cached observers that implemen IRemoteObserver interface that defines Dispose method.

I've done a pass.

> Any test that we have executes this code. I can't think of a good way to unit test this though.

A couple ideas:
- Submit an evaluator request with no runtime and ensure that the default is chosen.
- Submit an evaluator request with an unconfigured runtime and validate that the right exception is returned.
- Submit an evaluator request with a supported runtime and validate that it ends up in the right runtime.

On the C# side, we could validate all of these by monitoring calls to the bridge to avoid calls into Java as part of unit tests.
@markusweimer Updated.
@markusweimer will add some tests :)
LGTM. @dafrista Can you have a look at the vortex messages?
@jwang98052 I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!

@jwang98052 rebased.

@afchung You mean `TestDriverConfigGenerator` failure to extract files? I think we need to do REEF-1293 for it. I'd like to have as few tests in the same test collection as possible, to speed them up.

@shulmanb I'm not sure I understand -- if you have a remote observers factory, the only thing it does is creates connections that are "managed" by the client, i.e. the factory doesn't cache the connection, nor does it care about what happens to the connection. In that sense, you can return an object that is both `IObservable` _and_ `IDisposable` without changing the current interface at all.
@shulmanb did you push your latest changes? I only see one new commit since the initial pull request.
@tcNickolas yes, I didn't realize we have an item for it already :)
I filed it specifically based on this discussion :-) Let's handle it separately, as it's not related to this change
Ok, are you OK with merging this one then, @tcNickolas? It passes the tests eventually, and gets rid of the super-annoying dialog boxes.
@afchung Pushed it now. Sorry.

@afchung What proxy observers are doing is creating both outgoing connection and also listening on incoming connection and forward requests to local observers. I want to preserve that functionality, but handle recreating and disposing of connections myself.
@afchung Current interface returns IObserver for the remote connection so I have to change it to return IDisposable as well

I'm concerned about `StreamingRemoteManagerTest` tests which don't even try to run. I've never seen such behavior on my machine, but these are the same group of tests which get stuck on AppVeyor. Could you maybe try and repro this effect on the same machine with master branch? So that we know it's not introduced by this change?
I will test and merge

I'm open to suggestions for other information that would be nice to reflect on this page.
The link to JIRA issue and is incorrect. The commit message on the base commit is also outdated, please be careful before final push.

> Apache REEF (Retainable Evaluator Execution Framework) is a scale-out computing fabric

In my expierence, saying that REEF is a standard library for building distributed systems works much better. The "fabric" sounds way too vague for many people.

> For example, Azure Stream Analytics is built on REEF

My academic background tells me this statement asks for a reference :)

> The developer mailinglist 

Small typo: mailinglist -> mailing list

> other information that would be nice to reflect on this page

The current release version as a badge would be nice.

@markusweimer The `BroadcastReduce`, `PipelinedBroadcastReduce`, and `ScatterReduce` tests have always been intermittently failing for me, and there has always been a JIRA item opened for these tests. After looking into the logs, I believe the root cause is due to calling `Unregister` prematurely in `INameClient` and due to calling `Dispose` on `INameClient` multiple times. This is because both `NetworkService` and `StreamingNetworkService` share the same `INameClient`. Given that none of them actually create the `INameClient` itself, the `NetworkService` s should not be the one to `Dispose` the `INameClient`.

Thanks, @afchung.

The net of this is that our tests fail differently when merging this particular PR. What shall we do about that?

@markusweimer I'll see if I can fix up the failure first and send out a PR. You can then merge from that PR's branch with this branch and see if the failure reproduces here. If it does not repro, I would think that the change is safe, otherwise there's probably something wrong caused by the changes in this PR.
Can you add a unit test for this? Without the test, it's fairly hard to verify the behavior change.
I will review it.

Right, you should add a test case. Basically have an injectacble constructor A and put another injectable class B as a named parameter in the constructor. The test should try to inject A and  expect the exception.

You mean ignore Version and other unrelated fields? Yes, I think that should be fine.

So, I tried to merge the change. It looked like a benign conflict in a `.csproj` file that i was able to resolve. However, once I did that _none_ of the functional tests passed anymore. They pass (mostly) on current `master` on the same machine.
